statement.p: Let V={\mathbb R}. For u,v \in V and a\in{\mathbb R} define vector addition by u \boxplus v := u+v + 3 and scalar multiplication by a \boxdot u := au + 3a - 3. It can be shown that (V,\boxplus,\boxdot) is a vector space over the scalar field \mathbb R. Find the following:
(a) The sum 5\boxplus -6
(b) The scalar multiple 8\boxdot 5
(c) The zero vector, \underline{0}_V
(d) The additive inverse of x, \boxminus x

Let V=(-5,\infty). For u,v \in V and a\in{\mathbb R} define vector addition by u \boxplus v := uv + 5(u+v)+20 and scalar multiplication by a \boxdot u := (u + 5)^a - 5. It can be shown that (V,\boxplus,\boxdot) is a vector space over the scalar field \mathbb R. Find the following:
(a) The sum -1\boxplus 1
(b) The scalar multiple 2\boxdot -1
(c) The additive inverse of -1, \boxminus -1
(d) The zero vector, \underline{0}_V
(e) The additive inverse of x, \boxminus x
A square matrix A is idempotent if A^2 = A.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries. Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 idempotent matrices with real entries. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
(a) Does H contain the zero vector of V?
(b) Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two idempotent matrices A and B such that (A+B)^2 \ne (A+B).)
(c) Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and an idempotent matrix A such that (rA)^2 \ne (rA).)
(d) Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts a-c.

p.m: \text{H contains the zero vector of V}
\text{H is not a subspace of V}

statement.p: The trace of a square n \times n matrix A = (a_{ij}) is the sum a_{11} + a_{22} + \cdots + a_{nn} of the entries on its main diagonal.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries.
Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries that have trace 0. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
(a) Does H contain the zero vector of V?
(b) Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two trace zero matrices A and B such that A+B has nonzero trace.)
(c) Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and a trace zero matrix A such that rA has nonzero trace.)
(d) Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts a-c.

p.m: \text{H contains the zero vector of V}

statement.p: The trace of a square n \times n matrix A = (a_{ij}) is the sum a_{11} + a_{22} + \cdots + a_{nn} of the entries on its main diagonal.
Let V be the vector space of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries. Let H be the set of all 2 \times 2 matrices with real entries that have trace 1. Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
(a) Does H contain the zero vector of V?
(b) Is H closed under addition?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under addition, it is sufficient to find two trace one matrices A and B such that A+B has trace not equal to one.)
(c) Is H closed under scalar multiplication?
(Hint: to show that H is not closed under scalar multiplication, it is sufficient to find a real number r and a trace one matrix A such that rA has trace not equal to one.)
(d) Is H a subspace of the vector space V?
You should be able to justify your answer by writing a complete, coherent, and detailed proof based on your answers to parts a-c.

p.m: \text{H does not contain the zero vector of V}
\text{H is not a subspace of V}

statement.p: Let V be the vector space of symmetric 2\times 2 matrices and W be the subspace W=\operatorname{span} \left\{ {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 \amp -5\cr -5 \amp -3 \end{array}\right]},{\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 \amp 4\cr 4 \amp 4 \end{array}\right]} \right\} .
(a) Find a nonzero element X in W.
(b) Find an element Y in V that is not in W.
Let V be the vector space P_3(\mathbb{R}) of polynomials in x with degree less than 3 and W be the subspace W=\operatorname{span} \left\lbrace {5+3x+3x^{2}},{6x-5-2x^{2}} \right\rbrace .
(a) Find a nonzero polynomial p(x) in W.
(b) Find a polynomial q(x) in V that does not belong to W.
If possible, write {24+8x+14x^{2}} as a linear combination of {2+x+x^{2}}, {-2-x^{2}} and {-3-x-2x^{2}}.
Let x, y, z be (non-zero) vectors and suppose w = -20x-10y+4z.
If z= 4x+2y, then w = x+ y.
Using the calculation above, mark the statements below that must be true.

li.p: Span(x, y, z) = Span(w, x, y)

statement.p: Are the vectors \vec{u}= {\left[\begin{array}{c} -4\cr -3\cr -3 \end{array}\right]}, \vec{v} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} 3\cr -1\cr -4 \end{array}\right]} and \vec{w} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -7\cr -15\cr -24 \end{array}\right]} linearly independent?
If they are linearly dependent, find scalars that are not all zero such that the equation below is true.
If they are linearly independent, find the only scalars that will make the equation below true.
\vec{u} + \vec{v} + \vec{w} = \vec{0}.
If they are linearly dependent, find scalars that are not all zero such that the equation below is true.
If they are linearly independent, find the only scalars that will make the equation below true.
\vec{u} + \vec{v} + \vec{w} = \vec{0}.
Are the vectors p(x) = {5x-4+3x^{2}}, q(x) = {7x-6+4x^{2}} and r(x) = {1-2x-x^{2}} linearly independent?
If the vectors are independent, enter zero in every answer blank below, since zeros are only the values that make the equation below true.
If they are dependent, find numbers, not all zero, that make the equation below true. You should be able to explain and justify your answer.
Are the vectors p(x) = {3x-3-9x^{2}}, q(x) = {4+12x-8x^{2}} and r(x) = {-5-7x} linearly independent?
If the vectors are independent, enter zero in every answer blank since zeros are only the values that make the equation below true.
If they are dependent, find numbers, not all zero, that make the equation below true. You should be able to explain and justify your answer.
Determine whether or not the following sets S of 2\times 2 matrices are linearly independent.

Find a basis \lbrace p(x), q(x) \rbrace for the vector space \lbrace f(x)\in P_2(\mathbb{R}) \mid f'(3)=f(1) \rbrace where P_2(\mathbb{R}) is the vector space of polynomials in x with degree less than or equal to 2.
Find a basis for the vector space \lbrace A\in M_{22}(\mathbb R) \mid \text{tr}(A)=0\rbrace of 2\times 2 matrices with trace 0.
Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that \dim(S_2) = 3.
(a) What are the possible dimensions of S_1?
(b) If S_1\neq S_2 then what are the possible dimensions of S_1?

solution.p: (a) The dimension of S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2 since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 is non-zero, and thus its dimension cannot be 0. Hence 1, 2, or 3 are the possible dimensions of S_1.
(b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. Thus only 1 or 2 are possible dimensions of S_1 .

statement.p: Let P_2 be the vector space of all polynomials of degree 2 or less, and let H be the subspace spanned by {7x^{2}-x-2}, \ {4x^{2}-1} and {2-\left(9x^{2}+x\right)}.
(a) What is the dimension of the subspace H?
(b) Is \lbrace {7x^{2}-x-2}, {4x^{2}-1}, {2-\left(9x^{2}+x\right)} \rbrace a basis for P_2?
Be sure you can explain and justify your answer.
(c) Give a basis for the subspace H.
Let P_2 be the vector space of all polynomials of degree 2 or less, and let H be the subspace spanned by {7x^{2}-10x-5}, \ {19x^{2}-7x-7} and {-\left(3x+1\right)}.
(a) What is the dimension of the subspace H?
(b) Is \lbrace {7x^{2}-10x-5}, {19x^{2}-7x-7}, {-\left(3x+1\right)} \rbrace a basis for P_2?
Be sure you can explain and justify your answer.
(c) Give a basis for the subspace H.

introduction.p: Let U=\spn\{{2x^{2}-1},{2x-4x^{2}}\} and W=\spn\{{4x^{3}-2x^{2}},{24x^{2}-8x-4}\} be subspaces of the vector space V=P_3(\R)\text{.}

statement.p: What is the dimension of U+W\text{?}
What is the dimension of U\cap W\text{?}

(a) Suppose f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{3} is a linear transformation such that f \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 3 \\ -4 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 5 \\ 3 \end{array} \right).Compute \displaystyle{ f \left( \begin{array}{r} -3 \\ 7 \end{array} \right)}.

(b) Suppose f : \mathbb{R}^{12} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} is a linear transformation such that f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_4 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -2 \\ 5 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_7 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -1 \\ -4 \end{array} \right), \quad f \left( \begin{array}{c} {\vec{e}}_8 \end{array} \right) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 5 \\ -3 \end{array} \right).Compute \displaystyle{ f ( 5 {\vec{e}}_4 + 4 {\vec{e}}_7 ) - f ( 6 {\vec{e}}_8 + 2 {\vec{e}}_7 )}.

(c) Let V be a vector space and let {\vec{v}}_1, {\vec{v}}_2, {\vec{v}}_3 \in V. Suppose T : V \to \mathbb{R}^{2} is a linear transformation such that T({\vec{v}}_1) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -3 \\ -2 \end{array} \right), \quad T({\vec{v}}_2) = \left( \begin{array}{r} 5 \\ 1 \end{array} \right), \quad T({\vec{v}}_3) = \left( \begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 3 \end{array} \right).Compute -4 T({\vec{v}}_1) + T(2 {\vec{v}}_2 + 5 {\vec{v}}_3).

Let M_{n,n}(\mathbb{R}) denote the vector space of n \times n matrices with real entries. Let f : M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) \to M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) be the function defined by f(A) = A^T for any A \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}). Determine if f is a linear transformation, as follows:

Let A = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} a_{11} \amp a_{12}\cr a_{21} \amp a_{22}\cr \end{array}\right]} and B = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} b_{11} \amp b_{12}\cr b_{21} \amp b_{22}\cr \end{array}\right]} be any two matrices in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R}) and let c \in \mathbb{R}.
Does f(A+B) = f(A) + f(B) for all A, B \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R})?
(b) f(c A) = .
c(f(A)) = \Bigg( \Bigg).
Does f(c A) = c(f(A)) for all c \in \mathbb{R} and all A \in M_{2,2}(\mathbb{R})?
(c) Is f a linear transformation?
Let f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} be defined by f(x) = {2x-3}. Determine if f is a linear transformation, as follows:
Does f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) for all x,y \in \mathbb{R}?
(b) f(c x) = .
c(f(x)) = \Big( \Big).
Does f(cx) = c(f(x)) for all c, x \in \mathbb{R}?
(c) Is f a linear transformation?
Let V and W be vector spaces and let \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2 \in V and \vec{w}_1, \vec{w}_2 \in W.
(a) Suppose T : V \to W is a linear transformation.
Find T( 6 \vec{v}_1 - \vec{v}_2) and write your answer in terms of T(\vec{v}_1) and T(\vec{v}_2).
(b) Suppose L : V \to W is a linear transformation such that L(\vec{v}_1) = \vec{w}_1 + \vec{w}_2 and L(\vec{v}_2) = - 8 \vec{w}_2.
Find L(6 \vec{v}_1 + 3 \vec{v}_2) in terms of \vec{w}_1 and \vec{w}_2.

Let T:{\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be a linear transformation that sends the vector \vec{u} =(5,2) into (2,1) and maps \vec{v}= (1,3) into (-1, 3). Use properties of a linear transformation to calculate the following.
Let T: {\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be a linear transformation that sends \vec{e}_1 to \vec{x}_1 and \vec{e}_2 to \vec{x}_2.
If T maps (1, 6) to the vector \vec{y}, find \vec{y}.

Let \vec{v}_1= {\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr -2 \end{array}\right]} \ \mbox{ and } \ \vec{v}_2={\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr -1 \end{array}\right]} . Let T:{\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be the linear transformation satisfying T(\vec{v}_1)={\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr -17 \end{array}\right]} \ \mbox{ and } \ T(\vec{v}_2)={\left[\begin{array}{c} 5\cr -13 \end{array}\right]} . Find the image T \left({\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr \end{array}\right]}\right) of an arbitrary vector {\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr \end{array}\right]} .

If T: {\mathbb R}^3 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^3 is a linear transformation such that T\left( {\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr 0\cr 0 \end{array}\right]} \right) = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -4\cr 0\cr -1 \end{array}\right]}, \quad T\left( {\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\cr 1\cr 0 \end{array}\right]} \right) = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 3\cr 3 \end{array}\right]}, \quad T\left( {\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\cr 0\cr 1 \end{array}\right]} \right) = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 3\cr -2 \end{array}\right]},
find the value of \ T \left({\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 4\cr 2 \end{array}\right]}\right).

introduction.p: Let T:P_3 \rightarrow P_3 be the linear transformation such that T(-2 x^2)= -4 x^2 - 4 x, \quad T(-0.5 x + 2)= 4 x^2 - 2 x + 1, \quad T(3 x^2 + 1) = -4 x - 4 .

statement.p: Compute T(1).
Compute T(x).
Compute T(x^2).
Compute T(ax^2+bx+c), where a, b, and c are arbitrary real numbers.
If T: P_1 \rightarrow P_1 is a linear transformation such that T(1+4 x) = -2 + 4 x \ and \ T(3 + 11 x) = 3 + 2 x, \ , find the value of T(4 - 5 x).
Let A={\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 4 \amp 4\cr -1 \amp -2 \amp -3\cr 0 \amp -2 \amp -1\cr -1 \amp -2 \amp -3 \end{array}\right]}.
Find a basis for the image of A (or, equivalently, for the linear transformation T(x)=Ax).

Let A = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -4 \amp -1 \amp 4\cr -1 \amp 2 \amp 1\cr -1 \amp 2 \amp 1\cr -8 \amp -2 \amp 8 \end{array}\right]}. Find dimensions of the kernel and image of T(\vec{x}) = A \vec{x}.

Let A = {\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp -2\cr 3 \amp 9 \amp 0 \amp -21 \end{array}\right]}. Find a vector \vec{w} in {\mathbb R}^3 that is not in the image of the transformation \vec{x}\mapsto A\vec{x}.

Suppose A \in M_{2,3}(\mathbb{R}) is a matrix and A \mathbf{e_1} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr -2 \end{array}\right]}, A \mathbf{e_2} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr -1 \end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } A \mathbf{e_3} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr 0 \end{array}\right]}.

li.p: Find the matrix for the linear transformation f (relative to the standard basis in the domain and codomain). That is, find the matrix A such that f(\mathbf{x}) = A \mathbf{x}.
Find a formula for the linear transformation f.
Find bases (i.e., maximal independent sets) for the kernel and image of f.
What is f( 2, -5 )? Enter your answer as a coordinate vector of the form \langle 1,2,3\rangle.
If f is a linear transformation, find the matrix A such that f(\mathbf{x}) = A \mathbf{x}.
Find bases (i.e., minimal spanning sets) for the kernel and image of f.

statement.p: Let f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} be the linear transformation defined by f(x,y) = \langle {5x+y}, {3x-3y} \rangle.

li.p: Find the matrix of the linear transformation f.
If f is bijective, find the matrix of its inverse.
Find the matrix of the linear transformation f.

statement.p: Let f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{3} be the linear transformation determined by f(\vec{e}_1)=\begin{pmatrix}-9 \\ 12 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}, \quad f(\vec{e}_2)=\begin{pmatrix}-15 \\ 20 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix}.

li.p: Find the matrix of the linear transformation f.

statement.p: Let L:\mathbb{R}^3 \to \mathbb{R}^3 be the linear operator defined by

p.me: L(x) = \begin{bmatrix}-12 x_1 - 24 x_2 + 12 x_3\\-12 x_2\\-36 x_1 + 36 x_3\end{bmatrix}

statement.p: (a) Find the dimension of the range of L:
(b) Find the dimension of the kernel of L:
(c) Let S be the subspace of \mathbb{R}^3 spanned by 11 e_1 and 24 e_2 + 24 e_3. Find the dimension of L(S):

solution.p: (a) Since e_1, e_2, e_3 spans \mathbb{R}^3, we get that L(\mathbb{R}^3) is spanned by L(e_1), L(e_2), L(e_3). So
and hence the dimension of the range is 2.
(b) The rank-nullity theorem implies that the dimension of the kernel is 3-2 = 1.
and it is easy to check that these two vectors are linearly independent. Therefore, the dimension of L(S) is 2.

statement.p: Let \mathcal{P}_n be the vector space of all polynomials of degree n or less in the variable x. Let D^2 : \mathcal{P}_4 \to \mathcal{P}_2 be the linear transformation that takes a polynomial to its second derivative. That is, D^2(p(x)) = p''(x) for any polynomial p(x) of degree 4 or less.

li.p: Find a basis for the kernel of D^2.
Find a basis for the image of D^2.

statement.p: Let T:P_3 \rightarrow P_3 be defined by T(ax^2+bx+c)=(4 a + b)x^2 + (-4 a - 4 b + c) x - a . Find the inverse of T.

li.p: The linear transformation T_1: R^2 \rightarrow R^2 is given by
The linear transformation T_2: R^3 \rightarrow R^3 is given by
Using T_1 from part a, it is given that:
Using T_2 from part b, it is given that:

statement.p: Let \left\lbrace \vec{e}_1, \ \vec{e}_2, \ \vec{e}_3, \ \vec{e}_4, \ \vec{e}_5, \ \vec{e}_6 \right\rbrace be the standard basis in {\mathbb R}^6. Find the length of the vector \vec{x} = 5\vec{e}_1 + 2\vec{e}_2 + 3\vec{e}_3 - 3\vec{e}_4 - 2\vec{e}_5 - 3\vec{e}_6.
Find the norm of \vec{x} and the unit vector \vec{u} in the direction of \vec{x} if \displaystyle{ \vec{x} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} 5\cr 2\cr -2\cr -3 \end{array}\right]}. }
Given that \len{\xx}=2, \len{\yy}=1\text{,} and \xx\dotp\yy=5\text{,} compute (5\xx-3\yy)\dotp (\xx+5\yy)\text{.}

hint.p: Use properties of the dot product to expand and simplify.

solution.p: Note that the distributive property, together with symmetry, let us handle this dot product using what is essentially FOIL:

statement.p: Let { \mathbf{u}_1, \mathbf{u}_2, \mathbf{u}_3 } be an orthonormal basis for an inner product space V. If
is so that \|\mathbf{v}\| = 26, \mathbf{v} is orthogonal to \mathbf{u}_3, and \langle \mathbf{v},\mathbf{u}_2 \rangle = -26, find the possible values for a, b, and c.

solution.p: Solution: One checks by direct computation that

statement.p: Find two linearly independent vectors perpendicular to the vector \vec{v}= {\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr 5\cr 7 \end{array}\right]}.

Let \mathbf{x}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}-5\\3\\0\\-3\\0\\1\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{x}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}-3\\0\\2\\3\\0\\-1\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{x}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}-1\\0\\0\\0\\4\\-4\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.

Let \mathbf{x}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\0\\4\\0\\4\\-3\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{x}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\-4\\2\\0\\4\\0\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{x}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}3\\0\\4\\-1\\1\\0\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.

Let \mathbf{x}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}0\\0\\3\\11\\1\\0\\\end{array}\right]}, \mathbf{x}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\0\\2\\0\\2\\2\\\end{array}\right]}, \text{ and } \mathbf{x}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c}2\\14\\2\\0\\2\\0\\\end{array}\right]}.
Use the Gram-Schmidt procedure to produce an orthogonal set with the same span.
Find orthonormal bases of the kernel and image of A.

Given v=\begin{bmatrix}{{\frac{5}{3}}}\\ {{\frac{8}{3}}}\\ {{\frac{5}{3}}}\end{bmatrix}, find the coordinates for v in the subspace W spanned by u_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}6\\ 6\\ -1\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad u_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ -4\\ -12\end{bmatrix}.
Note that u_{1} and u_{2} are orthogonal.
Let W be the set of all vectors {\left[\begin{array}{c} x\cr y\cr x+y\cr \end{array}\right]} with x and y real. Find a vector whose span is W^{\perp}.

Let \vec{u} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr 7\cr 3\cr 1 \end{array}\right]} and \vec{v} = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 4\cr 4\cr -3 \end{array}\right]}, and let W the subspace of {\mathbb R}^4 spanned by \vec{u} and \vec{v}. Find a basis of W^{\perp}, the orthogonal complement of W in \mathbb{R}^4.
Let y=\begin{bmatrix}5\\ -3\\ -6\end{bmatrix}, u_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}-4\\ -6\\ -2\end{bmatrix}, and u_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 2\\ -10\end{bmatrix}.
Compute the distance d from y to the plane in {\mathbb R}^3 spanned by u_{1} and u_{2}.

Given \vec{v}={\left[\begin{array}{c} -7\cr -10\cr 2\cr 10 \end{array}\right]}, find the closest point to \vec{v} in the subspace W spanned by {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr -2\cr -4\cr 1 \end{array}\right]} and {\left[\begin{array}{c} -2\cr -5\cr -1\cr -20 \end{array}\right]}.

Find the orthogonal projection of \vec{v}={\left[\begin{array}{c} 9\cr 2\cr -19 \end{array}\right]} onto the subspace W of {\mathbb R}^3 spanned by {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 6\cr -2 \end{array}\right]} and {\left[\begin{array}{c} 6\cr -6\cr -21 \end{array}\right]}.
Find the characteristic polynomial of the matrix A = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp -2 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 4 \amp -4\cr -3 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]}.
Find the three distinct real eigenvalues of the matrix B = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -1 \amp 4 \amp 7\cr 0 \amp -4 \amp -8\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 7 \end{array}\right]}.

The matrix A={\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -8 \amp -4 \amp -12\cr -4 \amp -8 \amp -12\cr 4 \amp 4 \amp 8 \end{array}\right]} has two real eigenvalues, one of multiplicity 1 and one of multiplicity 2. Find the eigenvalues and a basis for each eigenspace.

The matrix A={\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 5 \amp 2 \amp -14 \amp 2\cr -2 \amp 1 \amp 5 \amp -2\cr 1 \amp 1 \amp -4 \amp 1\cr 1 \amp 1 \amp -7 \amp 4 \end{array}\right]} has two distinct real eigenvalues \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2. Find the eigenvalues and a basis for each eigenspace.
The matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 \amp 1 \amp 0\cr -9 \amp -4 \amp 1\cr k \amp 0 \amp 0\cr \end{array}\right] has three distinct real eigenvalues if and only if
\lt k \lt .

The matrix A=\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 4 \amp -4 \amp -8 \amp -4\cr -2 \amp 2 \amp 4 \amp 2\cr 2 \amp -2 \amp -4 \amp -2\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] has two real eigenvalues \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2. Find these eigenvalues, their multiplicities, and the dimensions of their corresponding eigenspaces.
The smaller eigenvalue \lambda_1 = has multiplicity and the dimension of its corresponding eigenspace is .
The larger eigenvalue \lambda_2= has multiplicity and the dimension of its corresponding eigenspace is .

Supppose A is an invertible n\times n matrix and \vec{v} is an eigenvector of A with associated eigenvalue 3. Convince yourself that \vec{v} is an eigenvector of the following matrices, and find the associated eigenvalues.

li.p: The eigenvalue of the matrix A^{8}.
The eigenvalue of the matrix A^{-1}.
The eigenvalue of the matrix A - 3 I_n.
The eigenvalue of the matrix -3 A.

statement.p: Let \vec{v}_1={\left[\begin{array}{c} 0\cr -3\cr -1 \end{array}\right]}, \vec{v}_2 = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr 3\cr 0 \end{array}\right]}, \vec{v}_3 = {\left[\begin{array}{c} -1\cr 0\cr 1 \end{array}\right]} be eigenvectors of the matrix A which correspond to the eigenvalues \lambda_1 = -1, \lambda_2 = 0, and \lambda_3 = 4, respectively, and let \vec{x}={\left[\begin{array}{c} 2\cr 3\cr 3 \end{array}\right]}.
Express \vec{x} as a linear combination \vec{x} =a\vec{v}_1 + b\vec{v}_2 +c\vec{v}_3, and find A\vec{x}.
Recall that similarity of matrices is an equivalence relation; that is, the relation is reflexive, symmetric and transitive.
Verify that A={\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 \amp 1\cr 1 \amp -1 \end{array}\right]} is similar to itself by finding a T such that A = T^{-1} A T.

We know that A and B={\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp -1\cr 1 \amp -2 \end{array}\right]} are similar since A = P^{-1} B P where P = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp -1\cr 2 \amp -3 \end{array}\right]}.
Verify that B\sim A by finding an S such that B = S^{-1} A S.

We also know that B and C={\left[\begin{array}{cc} -3 \amp 5\cr -1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]} are similar since B = Q^{-1} C Q where Q = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp 1\cr 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]}.
Verify that A\sim C by finding an R such that A = R^{-1} C R.
Determine the quadratic form Q(\vec{x}) = \vec{x}^TA\vec{x} associated to the matrix A = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 \amp -7 \amp 1\cr -7 \amp -8 \amp -9\cr 1 \amp -9 \amp -6 \end{array}\right]}.

The matrix A = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -4.6 \amp 0 \amp 1.2\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 1.2 \amp 0 \amp -1.4 \end{array}\right]} has three distinct eigenvalues, \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 \lt \lambda_3. Find the eigenvalues, and classify the quadratic form Q(\mathbf{x}) = \mathbf{x}^TA\mathbf{x}.

Suppose A is a 3 \times 3 matrix with real entries that has a complex eigenvalue {7-i} with corresponding eigenvector {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3+9i\cr 1\cr -6i \end{array}\right]}. Find another eigenvalue and eigenvector for A.
Give an example of a [`2 times 2 `] matrix with no real eigenvalues.
Find all the eigenvalues (real and complex) of the matrix M = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 5 \amp 8 \amp 17\cr 3 \amp 0 \amp 5\cr -3 \amp -3 \amp -8 \end{array}\right]}.

Find all the eigenvalues (real and complex) of the matrix M = {\left[\begin{array}{cccc} -7 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp -3\cr -13 \amp -1 \amp -4 \amp -5\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\cr 19 \amp 0 \amp 5 \amp 7 \end{array}\right]}.
Let M = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} -4 \amp 9\cr -9 \amp -4 \end{array}\right]}. Find formulas for the entries of M^n, where n is a positive integer. (Your formulas should not contain complex numbers.)

Let M = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -2 \amp -4 \amp 4\cr 4 \amp -2 \amp -8\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp -2 \end{array}\right]}. Find formulas for the entries of M^n, where n is a positive integer. (Your formulas should not contain complex numbers.)

Let M = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -1 \amp 3 \amp 2\cr 3 \amp -2 \amp -2\cr 2 \amp -2 \amp -3 \end{array}\right]}. Find c_1, c_2, and c_3 such that M^3 + c_1 M^2 + c_2 M + c_3 I_3 = 0, where I_3 is the 3\times 3 identity matrix.
Find the singular values \sigma_1 \ge \sigma_2 of A = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} -8 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 4 \end{array}\right]}.
Find the singular values \sigma_1 \ge \sigma_2 \ge \sigma_3 of A = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 5 \amp 0 \amp -3\cr 3 \amp 0 \amp 5 \end{array}\right]}.
Find the QR factorization of the matrix {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 4 \amp 4\cr 6 \amp 13\cr 12 \amp 33 \end{array}\right]}.
Find the QR factorization of the matrix {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 \amp 5 \amp 7\cr 4 \amp -8 \amp 11\cr 4 \amp 1 \amp -1 \end{array}\right]}.
Let \mathcal{P}_{n} be the vector space of all polynomials of degree n or less in the variable x.

Let D : \mathcal{P}_{3} \to \mathcal{P}_{2} be the linear transformation defined by D(p(x)) = p'(x). That is, ( D ) is the derivative transformation. Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace 1,6x,9x^2,5x^3 \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace 8,6x,7x^2 \rbrace, \end{array}be ordered bases for \mathcal{P}_{3} and \mathcal{P}_{2}, respectively. Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}\mathcal{C}}(D) for D relative to the basis \mathcal{B} in the domain and \mathcal{C} in the codomain.

Let \mathcal{P}_{n} be the vector space of all polynomials of degree n or less in the variable x. Let D : \mathcal{P}_{3} \to \mathcal{P}_{2} be the linear transformation defined by D(p(x)) = p'(x). That is, D is the derivative transformation.

Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace {1}, {x}, {x^{2}}, {x^{3}} \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace {-2-x-x^{2}}, {2+2x+x^{2}}, {3+3x+2x^{2}} \rbrace, \end{array}be ordered bases for \mathcal{P}_{3} and \mathcal{P}_{2}, respectively. Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}\mathcal{C}}(D) for D relative to the bases \mathcal{B} in the domain and \mathcal{C} in the codomain.

Let \mathcal{P}_{n} be the vector space of all polynomials of degree n or less in the variable x. Let D : \mathcal{P}_{3} \to \mathcal{P}_{2} be the linear transformation defined by D(p(x)) = p'(x). That is, D is the derivative transformation.

Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace {-1+x+x^{2}+x^{3}}, {-1+2x+x^{2}+x^{3}}, {-3+3x+2x^{2}+2x^{3}}, {-4+4x+3x^{2}+2x^{3}} \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace {1}, {x}, {x^{2}} \rbrace, \end{array}be ordered bases for \mathcal{P}_{3} and \mathcal{P}_{2}, respectively. Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}\mathcal{C}}(D) for D relative to the bases \mathcal{B} in the domain and \mathcal{C} in the codomain.

Let f : \mathbb{R}^{3} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} be the linear transformation defined by f(\vec{x}) = {\left[\begin{array}{ccc} -1 \amp 1 \amp -3\cr 1 \amp 3 \amp -4 \end{array}\right]} \vec{x}.Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt 2,-1,1\right>}, {\left\lt 2,-2,1\right>}, {\left\lt 1,-2,1\right>} \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt -1,2\right>}, {\left\lt -3,7\right>} \rbrace, \end{array}be bases for \mathbb{R}^{3} and \mathbb{R}^{2}, respectively. Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}\mathcal{C}}(f) for f relative to the bases \mathcal{B} in the domain and \mathcal{C} in the codomain.

Let f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{3} be the linear transformation defined by f(\vec{x}) = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 \amp -3\cr 1 \amp -2\cr 3 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]} \vec{x}.Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt -1,-2\right>}, {\left\lt -1,-3\right>} \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt 2,-1,1\right>}, {\left\lt -2,2,-1\right>}, {\left\lt 3,-3,2\right>} \rbrace, \end{array}be bases for \mathbb{R}^{2} and \mathbb{R}^{3}, respectively. Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}\mathcal{C}}(f) for f relative to the bases \mathcal{B} in the domain and \mathcal{C} in the codomain.

Let \vec{b}_1 = {\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\cr -2 \end{array}\right]} and \vec{b}_2= {\left[\begin{array}{c} -3\cr 7 \end{array}\right]}. The set B= \left\lbrace \vec{b}_1, \vec{b}_2 \right\rbrace is a basis for {\mathbb R}^2.
Let T: {\mathbb R}^2 \rightarrow {\mathbb R}^2 be a linear operator such that T(\vec{b}_1) = 6 \vec{b}_1 + 2 \vec{b}_2 and T(\vec{b}_2) = 8 \vec{b}_1 + 2 \vec{b}_2.

li.p: Find the matrix M_B(T) of T relative to the basis B.
Find the matrix M_E(T) of T relative to the standard basis E for {\mathbb R}^2.

introduction.p: Let f : \mathbb{R}^{2} \to \mathbb{R}^{2} be the linear operator defined by f(\vec{x}) = {\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 \amp 0\cr -1 \amp 3 \end{array}\right]} \vec{x}.Let \begin{array}{lcl} \mathcal{B} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt 1,-1\right>}, {\left\lt 1,-2\right>} \rbrace, \\ \mathcal{C} \amp = \amp \lbrace {\left\lt 1,-2\right>}, {\left\lt -3,5\right>} \rbrace, \end{array}be two different bases for \mathbb{R}^{2}.

statement.p: Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{B}}(f) for f relative to the basis \mathcal{B}.
Find the matrix M_{\mathcal{C}}(f) for f relative to the basis \mathcal{C}.
Find the transition matrix P_{\mathcal{B}\leftarrow\mathcal{C}} such that C_{\mathcal{B}}(v) = P_{\mathcal{B}\leftarrow\mathcal{C}}C_{\mathcal{C}}(v).
Find the transition matrix P_{\mathcal{C}\leftarrow\mathcal{B}} such that C_{\mathcal{C}}(v) = P_{\mathcal{C}\leftarrow\mathcal{B}}C_{\mathcal{B}}(v).
On paper, confirm that P_{\mathcal{C}\leftarrow\mathcal{B}}M_{\mathcal{B}}(f)P_{\mathcal{B}\leftarrow\mathcal{C}} = M_{\mathcal{C}}(f).
Find the minimal polynomial m(x) of {\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 2 \amp -2 \amp 5 \amp 2\cr 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp -3 \amp -3 \amp 3\cr 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \end{array}\right]}.

Let A={\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 28 \amp -34 \amp -65 \amp 24\cr 3 \amp -4 \amp -10 \amp 3\cr 3 \amp -2 \amp -3 \amp 3\cr -15 \amp 22 \amp 41 \amp -11 \end{array}\right]}. Find a matrix P such that D=P^{-1} A P is the Jordan canonical form of A.

Let A={\left[\begin{array}{cccc} -6 \amp 2 \amp 6 \amp -8\cr 0 \amp -2 \amp 4 \amp -4\cr -8 \amp 6 \amp 16 \amp -28\cr -5 \amp 4 \amp 13 \amp -22 \end{array}\right]}. Find a matrix P such that D=P^{-1} A P is the Jordan canonical form of A.
